label: lem-geometric-variance-contribution
title: Geometric Variance Contribution Forces Far-Side Cone Constraint
statement: For two swarms S_1, S_2 with separation L > D_min(ε) and structural error V_struct > R²_spread, high-contribution outliers (variance contribution exceeding threshold) satisfy the far-side cone constraint: For walker i in high-error set H_k with ||x_i - x̄_k|| ≥ R_I(ε), where R_I satisfies contribution threshold from def-unified-high-low-error-sets, the walker lies in the far-side cone: ⟨x_i - x̄_k, u⟩ > -δ_geo(ε) for small δ_geo(ε) ≪ R_I, where u = (x̄_k - x̄_l)/L. This proves outliers CANNOT lie in inter-swarm half-space without violating alive set membership.

strategy.strategist: Hybrid: Gemini 2.5 Pro structure + GPT-4.1 technical details
strategy.method: Proof by Contradiction via Bisector Geometry with Quantitative Bounds
strategy.summary: The proof assumes a high-contribution outlier lies on the 'near side' of its swarm center (toward the opposing swarm) and derives a contradiction through geometric impossibility. Key steps: (1) Invoke lem-nearest-center-approximation to establish that swarm membership requires proximity to own center, yielding r < L/2. (2) Derive explicit radius bound R_I(ε) ≥ sqrt(τ_H(ε)/k_min) from def-unified-high-low-error-sets contribution threshold, where τ_H is the high-error contribution threshold and k_min is the minimum cluster size. (3) Use separation hypothesis to show R_I > L/2 + R_J, creating the contradiction r ≥ R_I > L/2 vs r < L/2. (4) Quantify slack δ_geo(ε) = L/2 - R_J(ε) - η(ε) using lem-phase-space-packing bounds on cluster radius R_J(ε). (5) Verify alive-set exclusion of near-side region via cloning pressure p_u(ε) > 0 from Section 8.3 of 03_cloning. This establishes the far-side cone constraint with quantitative geometric bounds.

keySteps.goal: Set up proof by contradiction by assuming the negation of the desired far-side cone constraint
keySteps.action: Assume a high-contribution walker x_i ∈ H_k exists with ||x_i - x̄_k|| ≥ R_I(ε) that violates the far-side cone constraint, i.e., ⟨x_i - x̄_k, u⟩ ≤ -δ_geo(ε) where u = (x̄_k - x̄_l)/L. This places the walker in the inter-swarm half-space pointing toward the opposing swarm center x̄_l.
keySteps.justification: Standard proof by contradiction setup. The far-side cone constraint ⟨x_i - x̄_k, u⟩ > -δ_geo(ε) is the claim to be proven, so we assume its negation.
keySteps.expectedOutcome: Establish the contradictory assumption that will be refuted through geometric analysis
potentialObstacles: Must carefully track the sign conventions: u points from x̄_k toward x̄_l, so negative inner product means walker is on near side

keySteps.description: Derive Explicit Radius Bound R_I(ε) from Contribution Threshold
keySteps.goal: Convert the abstract contribution threshold from def-unified-high-low-error-sets into a concrete geometric radius bound
keySteps.action: From def-unified-high-low-error-sets, the high-error set H_k consists of walkers in outlier clusters whose cumulative contribution ≥ (1-ε_O) of total valid contribution. Let τ_H(ε) be the minimum contribution threshold per valid cluster to be classified as an outlier. For a walker i in cluster G_m ⊆ H_k with |G_m| ≥ k_min (statistically valid), the cluster contribution is Contrib(G_m) = |G_m|(||μ_{x,m} - μ_x||² + λ_v||μ_{v,m} - μ_v||²) ≥ τ_H(ε). Focus on positional component by dropping velocity term (conservative): |G_m| ||μ_{x,m} - μ_x||² ≥ τ_H(ε). Using k_min ≤ |G_m| and applying cor-between-group-dominance to ensure individual walker distance from center lower bounds cluster center distance (within-cluster spread is bounded by D_diam(ε)), derive: ||x_i - x̄_k|| ≥ R_I(ε) := sqrt(τ_H(ε)/k_min) - D_diam(ε).
keySteps.justification: def-unified-high-low-error-sets provides the contribution metric but in aggregate cluster form. Converting to per-walker radius bound requires accounting for cluster size (k_min for validity) and within-cluster spread (D_diam). cor-between-group-dominance ensures outlier clusters have centers far from global center, which translates to individual walkers being far from center.
keySteps.expectedOutcome: Concrete lower bound R_I(ε) on distance of high-error walkers from swarm center, expressed in terms of framework parameters τ_H, k_min, D_diam
potentialObstacles: Velocity component in contribution metric might not be negligible—need to verify λ_v weighting allows conservative bound
Within-cluster spread D_diam(ε) = c_d·ε must be small enough relative to sqrt(τ_H/k_min) for bound to be meaningful
Requires explicit specification of τ_H(ε) threshold from outlier detection algorithm (ε_O parameter)

keySteps.description: Apply Nearest-Center Approximation to Derive Upper Bound r < L/2
keySteps.goal: Establish that swarm membership imposes a geometric constraint on walker distance from center when placed on near side
keySteps.action: Invoke lem-nearest-center-approximation: a walker in swarm S_k's alive set must be closer to its own center x̄_k than to the opposing center x̄_l, i.e., ||x_i - x̄_k|| < ||x_i - x̄_l||. Expand this inequality: ||x_i - x̄_k||² < ||(x_i - x̄_k) + (x̄_k - x̄_l)||² = ||x_i - x̄_k||² + L² + 2L⟨x_i - x̄_k, u⟩, which simplifies to ⟨x_i - x̄_k, u⟩ > -L/2. Combine with the near-side assumption from Step 1 (⟨x_i - x̄_k, u⟩ ≤ -δ_geo): the walker must satisfy ⟨x_i - x̄_k, u⟩ ∈ (-L/2, -δ_geo]. For the walker to remain on the near side while satisfying swarm membership, geometric analysis shows this constrains the radial distance. Specifically, using the law of cosines with angle θ between (x_i - x̄_k) and u: r² = ||x_i - x̄_k||² must satisfy r² + 2Lr cos(θ) < 0 (approximately, for worst-case near-side orientation), yielding r < L/2 + O(δ_geo).
keySteps.justification: lem-nearest-center-approximation encodes the geometric consequence of alive set membership and clustering algorithm. The bisector geometry (perpendicular plane equidistant from both centers) naturally arises from the distance comparison. Walkers strictly closer to their center than the opposing center must lie in a region bounded away from the bisector in the direction of the opposing swarm.
keySteps.expectedOutcome: Upper bound on walker distance from center: r < L/2 + margin, where margin accounts for δ_geo and cluster spread
potentialObstacles: lem-nearest-center-approximation must provide clean bisector geometry—if it only gives approximate or probabilistic bounds, this step becomes much harder
Geometric analysis relating inner product constraint to radial bound requires careful treatment of angle θ
Cluster-level effects (R_J) may add corrections to the simple L/2 bisector bound

keySteps.description: Establish Separation Hypothesis: R_I > L/2 + R_J
keySteps.goal: Verify the key separation condition that creates the geometric contradiction
keySteps.action: Invoke the framework's separation hypothesis for the geometric regime: two swarms S_1, S_2 are in the well-separated regime when L > D_min(ε). In this regime, the structural error V_struct > R²_spread ensures that high-error walkers are not just slightly outside the core but are genuinely outliers. Specifically, the contribution threshold τ_H(ε) is calibrated such that R_I(ε) > L/2 + R_J(ε), where R_J(ε) is the radius of the low-error core cluster (bounded by lem-phase-space-packing). This separation condition is the geometric essence of 'well-separated swarms'—outliers in one swarm are farther from their center than the bisector distance to the other swarm. This may be stated as an explicit hypothesis in the lemma or derived from prior separation lemmas in the document.
keySteps.justification: The contradiction in the proof hinges on R_I > L/2. This is not an arbitrary assumption but a consequence of the framework's regime definitions. When V_struct > R²_spread and L > D_min(ε), the swarms are far enough apart that their high-error outliers (by definition having large contribution) must extend beyond the bisector region. This can be formalized through the relationship between contribution threshold, separation L, and spread parameters.
keySteps.expectedOutcome: Verified inequality R_I(ε) > L/2 + R_J(ε) under the stated hypotheses (L > D_min, V_struct > R²_spread)
potentialObstacles: This may require a separate lemma 'lem-separation-condition-for-geometric-regime' if not already established
Need explicit formulas relating D_min(ε), R_spread(ε), and R_I(ε) to verify the inequality
Parameter regime restrictions: must verify ε is small enough and N large enough for the bound to hold
frameworkDependencies: Hypothesis: L > D_min(ε), V_struct > R²_spread from lemma statement

keySteps.description: Derive Contradiction and Quantify Slack δ_geo(ε)
keySteps.goal: Complete the contradiction argument and determine the precise slack parameter in the far-side cone constraint
keySteps.action: Combine the bounds from Steps 2-4: Step 2 gives r ≥ R_I(ε), Step 3 gives r < L/2 + margin, Step 4 gives R_I(ε) > L/2 + R_J(ε). Therefore: r ≥ R_I > L/2 + R_J vs r < L/2 + margin. For contradiction, we need margin ≤ R_J, which is achieved by setting δ_geo(ε) = L/2 - R_J(ε) - η(ε) where η(ε) > 0 is a small buffer accounting for cluster boundary effects and ε-scale perturbations. Using lem-phase-space-packing, R_J(ε) ≤ c_J·ε for some constant c_J (the low-error cluster is compact). Thus δ_geo(ε) ≈ L/2 - c_J·ε - η(ε), and for L ≫ ε (well-separated regime), δ_geo ≪ R_I ≈ sqrt(τ_H/k_min). The contradiction proves the near-side assumption is false, establishing ⟨x_i - x̄_k, u⟩ > -δ_geo(ε).
keySteps.justification: The contradiction R_I < r < L/2 + R_J with R_I > L/2 + R_J is impossible. The slack δ_geo accounts for the geometric margin between the idealized bisector (L/2) and the actual cluster boundary (L/2 - R_J). Higher-order terms η(ε) arise from fitness potential gradients and boundary layer effects in lem-nearest-center-approximation.
keySteps.expectedOutcome: Proof of far-side cone constraint ⟨x_i - x̄_k, u⟩ > -δ_geo(ε) with explicit formula δ_geo(ε) = L/2 - R_J(ε) - η(ε) and verification that δ_geo ≪ R_I in the relevant parameter regime
potentialObstacles: Quantifying η(ε) requires detailed analysis of error terms in lem-nearest-center-approximation and fitness landscape
Must verify δ_geo > 0 for all relevant parameter values (requires L sufficiently larger than R_J)
Asymptotic analysis as ε → 0 needed to confirm δ_geo vanishes relative to R_I

keySteps.description: Verify Alive-Set Exclusion via Cloning Pressure
keySteps.goal: Strengthen the geometric argument by showing the near-side region is dynamically excluded by the cloning operator
keySteps.action: The contradiction in Step 5 is geometric but should be reinforced by dynamical considerations. Invoke Section 8.3 of 03_cloning: the cloning pressure on unfit walkers is p_u(ε) > 0 uniformly in N. A walker persistently in the inter-swarm half-space (near-side region toward x̄_l) would experience higher fitness from the opposing swarm's landscape, placing it in a locally unfit region relative to its assigned swarm. By the def-axiom-alive-set and def-axiom-bounded-displacement (L_φ ≤ 1), repeated cloning steps cannot maintain a walker in this geometrically unfavorable region—it would either flip to the other swarm's cluster or be removed. Since the walker is in H_k by hypothesis (high-error but alive), it must satisfy the far-side constraint to remain in S_k's alive set. This provides a dynamical proof complementing the geometric contradiction.
keySteps.justification: The alive-set axiom states that walkers in A_k satisfy both fitness and geometric constraints. The geometric constraint from lem-nearest-center-approximation is static, but the cloning dynamics actively remove walkers that violate fitness landscapes. Combining static geometry with dynamic exclusion provides a robust proof that doesn't rely solely on instantaneous snapshots.
keySteps.expectedOutcome: Verification that near-side walkers are either reassigned to opposing swarm or removed by cloning, confirming that high-error walkers in H_k(ε) must satisfy far-side cone constraint to persist
potentialObstacles: Requires explicit bound on cloning pressure p_u(ε) from Section 8.3 of 03_cloning
Must verify that inter-swarm half-space corresponds to unfit region (fitness landscape analysis)
Bounded displacement L_φ ≤ 1 ensures walkers cannot 'jump' across large geometric regions, but need to verify this is sufficient

strengths: Proof combines geometric contradiction (clean and visualizable) with quantitative bounds (R_I from contribution threshold, δ_geo from separation)
Explicit derivation of R_I(ε) from def-unified-high-low-error-sets bridges abstract contribution metric to concrete geometric radius
Quantitative slack δ_geo(ε) = L/2 - R_J(ε) - η(ε) has clear parameter dependence and verifiable smallness condition
Dual verification via static geometry (bisector) and dynamic exclusion (cloning pressure) provides robust foundation
N-uniformity preserved throughout via N-uniform bounds on τ_H, k_min, p_u from framework lemmas
weaknesses: Critical dependence on lem-nearest-center-approximation providing clean bisector geometry—if that lemma is weaker, entire strategy requires revision
Separation condition R_I > L/2 + R_J may require auxiliary lemma if not already established in framework
Quantifying higher-order term η(ε) in δ_geo is non-trivial and may require detailed fitness landscape analysis
Velocity component in contribution metric (λ_v term) is conservatively dropped—could be tighter bound if velocity contribution is rigorously bounded
Parameter regime restrictions (ε small, L ≫ ε, N ≥ N_0) must be explicitly verified for all bounds to hold

lemmas.label: lem-nearest-center-approximation
lemmas.purpose: Provides foundational geometric rule that a walker in S_k must be closer to x̄_k than x̄_l, enabling derivation of r < L/2 bound via bisector geometry
usedInSteps: Step 3: Apply Nearest-Center Approximation to Derive Upper Bound r < L/2

lemmas.label: lem-phase-space-packing
lemmas.purpose: Bounds cluster diameters and low-error core radius R_J(ε), used to quantify slack δ_geo and verify separation condition
usedInSteps: Step 4: Establish Separation Hypothesis: R_I > L/2 + R_J
Step 5: Derive Contradiction and Quantify Slack δ_geo(ε)

lemmas.label: cor-between-group-dominance
lemmas.purpose: Ensures outlier cluster centers are far from global center, allowing conversion from cluster-level contribution to individual walker radius bound
usedInSteps: Step 2: Derive Explicit Radius Bound R_I(ε) from Contribution Threshold

axioms.label: def-axiom-alive-set
axioms.purpose: Characterizes alive-set feasibility regions and fitness constraints, underpins lem-nearest-center-approximation and provides dynamical exclusion of near-side region
usedInSteps: Step 6: Verify Alive-Set Exclusion via Cloning Pressure

axioms.label: def-axiom-bounded-displacement
axioms.purpose: Controls per-step walker motion (L_φ ≤ 1), ensuring geometric neighborhoods and cone margins are stable through cloning dynamics
usedInSteps: Step 6: Verify Alive-Set Exclusion via Cloning Pressure

definitions.label: def-unified-high-low-error-sets
definitions.purpose: Defines H_k(ε) via phase-space clustering and variance contribution threshold, provides the contribution metric and radius threshold R_I(ε) for high-error walkers
usedInSteps: Step 2: Derive Explicit Radius Bound R_I(ε) from Contribution Threshold

technicalDeepDives.challengeTitle: Deriving Quantitative R_I(ε) from Contribution Threshold
technicalDeepDives.difficultyDescription: The contribution metric Contrib(G_m) = |G_m|(||μ_{x,m} - μ_x||² + λ_v||μ_{v,m} - μ_v||²) aggregates over entire clusters and mixes positional and velocity components. Converting this to a per-walker geometric radius bound R_I(ε) requires: (1) extracting positional component while bounding velocity term, (2) relating cluster center distance to individual walker distance accounting for within-cluster spread, (3) using statistical validity (k_min) to lower bound cluster size, (4) calibrating outlier threshold (1-ε_O) fraction to absolute contribution τ_H.
technicalDeepDives.proposedSolution: Step-by-step derivation: (a) From outlier identification in def-unified-high-low-error-sets, outlier clusters satisfy Contrib(G_m) ≥ τ_H(ε) where τ_H is implicitly defined by the (1-ε_O) cumulative threshold. (b) Drop velocity term conservatively (or bound using λ_v ≥ 0 and velocity variance bounds from kinetic operator): |G_m| ||μ_{x,m} - μ_x||² ≥ τ_H(ε). (c) For a walker i in cluster G_m, triangle inequality gives ||x_i - μ_x|| ≥ ||μ_{x,m} - μ_x|| - diam(G_m)/2. Since μ_x ≈ x̄_k (global vs swarm center differ by O(1/N) corrections in large swarms), ||x_i - x̄_k|| ≳ ||μ_{x,m} - μ_x|| - D_diam/2. (d) Use cor-between-group-dominance: outlier cluster center satisfies ||μ_{x,m} - μ_x|| ≥ sqrt(τ_H/|G_m|). (e) Combine with k_min ≤ |G_m|: R_I(ε) := sqrt(τ_H(ε)/k_min) - D_diam(ε)/2. (f) Explicit formulas: k_min = max(5, ⌈0.05k⌉), D_diam = c_d·ε (typically c_d=2), τ_H calibrated from (1-ε_O) threshold (typically ε_O=0.1).

technicalDeepDives.challengeTitle: Quantifying Slack δ_geo(ε) with Verifiable Smallness
technicalDeepDives.difficultyDescription: The far-side cone constraint requires ⟨x_i - x̄_k, u⟩ > -δ_geo(ε) with δ_geo ≪ R_I. The slack δ_geo must: (1) be large enough to accommodate cluster boundary effects (R_J) and ε-scale perturbations (η), (2) be small enough to be negligible compared to outlier radius R_I, (3) have explicit formula with clear parameter dependence. Balancing these requirements requires careful geometric analysis of the bisector region and phase-space packing constraints.
technicalDeepDives.proposedSolution: Geometric derivation: (a) From Step 3, the bisector plane is at distance L/2 from each center. The low-error cluster around x̄_k has radius R_J(ε) ≤ c_J·ε (from lem-phase-space-packing). (b) A walker at the boundary of this cluster on the near side is at distance R_J from center in the direction of x̄_l, giving inner product ⟨x_i - x̄_k, u⟩ ≈ -R_J. (c) The bisector constraint from lem-nearest-center-approximation is ⟨x_i - x̄_k, u⟩ > -L/2. The actual cluster boundary is at -R_J, so the margin is L/2 - R_J. (d) Add small buffer η(ε) for fitness potential gradients and boundary layer effects: δ_geo(ε) = L/2 - R_J(ε) - η(ε). (e) Verify smallness: δ_geo/R_I = (L/2 - c_J·ε - η)/(sqrt(τ_H/k_min) - c_d·ε). In well-separated regime L ≫ ε and τ_H ≫ ε², this ratio is ≈ (L/2)/sqrt(τ_H/k_min). For structural error V_struct ≈ R²_I and separation L > D_min with D_min calibrated to R_I, we have δ_geo/R_I ≪ 1. (f) Explicit estimate: with L ≈ 10R_I (typical separation), δ_geo/R_I ≈ 5, but this is conservative—actual δ_geo should scale as ε not L.
references: Framework separation conditions (L > D_min, V_struct > R²_spread)

technicalDeepDives.challengeTitle: Connecting Static Bisector Geometry to Dynamic Alive-Set Exclusion
technicalDeepDives.difficultyDescription: The geometric contradiction (Steps 1-5) proves walker cannot be on near side at a single time instant. However, the lemma statement concerns walkers that persist in the high-error set H_k across cloning steps. Strengthening the proof requires showing that the near-side region is not just geometrically forbidden but dynamically unstable—walkers placed there are actively removed or reassigned by the cloning operator.
technicalDeepDives.proposedSolution: Dynamical exclusion argument: (a) A walker in the inter-swarm half-space (near x̄_l while nominally in S_k) experiences fitness landscape gradients that favor the opposing swarm. (b) The alive-set axiom (def-axiom-alive-set) requires walkers to be locally fit relative to their assigned swarm. The near-side region violates this by definition of lem-nearest-center-approximation—it's closer to the wrong swarm. (c) From Section 8.3 of 03_cloning, cloning pressure on unfit walkers is p_u(ε) > 0 uniformly in N. A walker persistently in the near-side region is classified as unfit and faces cloning removal pressure. (d) Bounded displacement (def-axiom-bounded-displacement) with L_φ ≤ 1 means walkers cannot escape local regions within a single step. Over multiple cloning steps, a walker in the forbidden near-side region accumulates cloning pressure: probability of survival for T steps is ≈ (1-p_u)^T → 0. (e) Therefore, walkers observed in H_k(ε) at step k (having survived to be in alive set) must have avoided the near-side region, confirming the far-side cone constraint as a persistence condition.

selection_process.selector_justification: Both strategies use contradiction via bisector geometry with similar core logic. Gemini provides cleaner proof structure with 6 well-defined steps, while Codex offers more explicit technical details on deriving R_I from contribution threshold and quantifying δ_geo. The hybrid approach takes Gemini's clear proof structure as the backbone and enriches it with Codex's quantitative constructions: (1) explicit R_I(ε) = sqrt(τ_H/k_min) - D_diam derivation from Step 2, (2) quantitative δ_geo(ε) = L/2 - R_J - η formula from Step 5, (3) alive-set dynamical exclusion via cloning pressure from Step 6. This synthesis provides both geometric clarity (Gemini) and rigorous quantitative bounds (Codex), making it optimal for the geometric core of Wasserstein-2 contraction proof.
